text: — Noon.
The fog thins a little, and the street sounds return outside the window: hoofbeats, hawkers shouting, the echo of a blacksmith striking iron. The tavern finally feels like a “normal day” again.
I set the morning’s cups back in place and straighten the chair that was knocked askew. My knuckles still tingle faintly.
But the harder I try to return to routine, the more I realize that sense of certainty hasn’t faded—like a thin wire stretched tight in my mind, reminding me: she’s still upstairs.
Footsteps sound on the stairs. The third step—I hold my breath without thinking.
Alicia comes downstairs.
She hasn’t put her armor back on, only draped her cloak loosely, like someone crawling out of a long dream. But her steps are steady—so practiced it feels like she belongs here.
“Are you… alright?”
“No.”
She answers too bluntly, and it catches me off guard.
“But at least today, I did one thing right.”
Her gaze flicks to the injury on my face and lingers, like she’s inspecting something she absolutely must keep intact.
“You didn’t get hit by the second punch.”
“You keep saying that—this ‘second punch’… what are you—”
“Shh.”
She raises one finger, like she’s stopping me from pushing open a door.
Then she does something even stranger—
She places a candle on the counter. Then a second. Then a third.
The candles are new, still tied with thin string, as if she prepared them ahead of time.
“…What are you doing?”
“Inviting you to dinner.”
She says it so casually, like she’s just borrowing a flame. But her eyes are tight—tight like she’s gripping a rope at the edge of a cliff.
“You’re inviting me?”
“Yes.”
“Tonight. A candlelight dinner.”
As if afraid I might refuse, her speech suddenly speeds up—she says more than before.
“I’ve missed you too many times.”
“Every time I tell myself: ‘Next time I’ll sound more normal,’ ‘next time I’ll make you smile first,’ ‘next time I won’t scare you.’”
Halfway through, she seems to choke on her own words, her mouth twisting into something not quite a smile.
“But next time is never enough.”
“So this time, I’m not waiting.”
Her fingertip taps lightly against the counter, like she’s finalizing a rule.
“Wipe the table clean. Salt goes on the left.”
When she says that, a glint—almost pride—flickers through her eyes, like she’s finally pinned reality in place with a small nail.
“…You even remember that.”
“I remember far more than that.”
She pauses, as if carefully measuring how much truth would scare you away.
“I’ve got a task coming up.”
“I might be busy. I might get hurt. I might…”
Her throat moves slightly. She swallows the rest, like saying it aloud would make it real.
“So tonight, I want to sit here and eat a meal like an ordinary person.”
She looks straight at me now—no riddles, no detours.
“Will you come?”

options.text: Option A: Agree and prepare dinner (you want to know what she keeps ‘missing’)
Option B: Refuse her (something about this is deeply wrong, and you don’t want to be pulled in)
